body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

Currently, SageMath has a `cdef class LazyImport` that constructs a "lazy import" object that in (almost every) way behave like the original object.

Example code

```
        sage: from sage.misc.lazy_import import LazyImport
        sage: my_integer = LazyImport('sage.rings.integer', 'Integer')
        sage: my_integer(4)
        4
```

This is done by defining `__getattr__` and `__call__` and `__repr__` etc. on objects of the `LazyImport` class.

There is one way where the `LazyImport` object cannot mimic the original object however: `type()`.

In practice, this is hardly a problem, but it is a problem in https://github.com/sagemath/sage/issues/41213

```
from sage.misc.lazy_import import LazyImport
TensorAlgebra = LazyImport('sage.algebras.tensor_algebra', 'TensorAlgebra')

TensorAlgebra(CombinatorialFreeModule(QQ, ["a", "b"]))  # works well, __call__ is overridden
```

but:

```
class Example(TensorAlgebra):
    pass

Example(CombinatorialFreeModule(QQ, ["a", "b"]))  # error!
```

the reason is that the class declaration is "syntactic sugar" for essentially the following

```
Example = type(TensorAlgebra).__new__(type(TensorAlgebra), 'Example', (TensorAlgebra,), {"__module__": "__main__", "__qualname__": "Example"})
```

which resolves to (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/64896883/what-does-it-mean-for-a-class-to-inherit-from-an-object-which-is-not-a-type)

```
Example = LazyImport.__new__(LazyImport, 'Example', (TensorAlgebra,), {"__module__": "__main__", "__qualname__": "Example"})
```

which makes `Example` an instance of `LazyImport` instead of a type.

I can think of a few quick fixes, but the easiest appears to be to redefine `LazyImport.__new__` to return `type.__new__(type, 'Example', (TensorAlgebra,), {...})` instead of a `LazyImport` instance.

However, when I try to override `__new__` (so that the result is something not an instance of `LazyImport`), I get

```
/home/user202729/sage/src/sage/misc/lazy_import.pyx:202:4: __new__ method of extension type will change semantics in a future version of Pyrex and Cython. Use __cinit__ instead.
```

is there a way to override `__new__` anyway? Or any other way?

------

Some other solutions I can think of include

- make `class LazyImport` no longer an extension class so that `__new__` is override-able. (not sure about the performance impact)
- redefine `tp_new` (?) (like what `cdef class Integer` is using)


edit: actually `tp_new` is re-assignable, as shown in `Integer` class in sage, as well as https://github.com/sagemath/sage/pull/41223 . I wonder why redefining `__new__` directly is not possible though.

### Describe the solution you'd like.

comment_data.body:
The answer is currently "no" but I think it's mostly because nobody has done it rather than because we're opposed to it.

The slightly difficult bit is the interaction with `__cinit__` - we put `__cinit__` in the `tp_new` slot but it's obviously a lot less flexible than `__new__` (you're required to return the correct type for example). That requires a bit of thought about how to do it right. The simplest answer might be "if you have `__new__` you can't have `__cinit__` (including derived classes)".

--------------------------

The other (semi-related) thing that I think we should do better is support for `cdef staticmethod` factory functions. They're always a bit awkward because arguments to `__cinit__` must be Python types. It'd be nice if there was a clean way to ban direct instantiation from Python but let you create an instance from Cython. There's workarounds but they aren't hugely nice.

title: [ENH] Can cdef class have customized `__new__`?
